Caption:
~
Biographies of the Seventeen Indian Buddhist Masters ~ known as the Nalanda Masters

17. Atisha (980-1054 C.E.)

Continuation

Inviting Atisha to Tibet

Although the Buddha Dharma had been brought to Tibet several centuries earlier through the efforts primarily of Guru Rinpoche Padmasambhava (Gu-ru Rin-po-che Pad-ma â€˜byung-gnas) and several others, this early flowering suffered a great setback due to repression by King Langdarma (Glang-dar-ma) (863 â€“ 906 C.E.). Few practitioners were left and afterwards many points were no longer properly understood. Many felt that the practices of ethical self-discipline and tantra were mutually exclusive and that enlightenment could be achieved through intoxication and various forms of sexual misconduct. Others believed that likewise contradictory were the teachings of Hinayana and Mahayana, leading respectively to liberation and enlightenment.

To be continued.

Download more information about the Nalanda Tradition and the seventeen Nalanda Masters: https://www.dropbox.com/sh/y4w2v4ss0toftk1/AADwe2pnp6kF-LGdavVh_8t5a?dl=0
(Folder "Dharma scriptures", subfolder "Nalanda Tradition")

The names of the seventeen Nalanda Masters are:
01. Nagarjuna (one of the Six Ornaments)
02. Aryadeva (one of the Six Ornaments)
03. Buddhapalita
04. Bhavaviveka
05. Chandrakirti
06. Shantideva
07. Shantarakshita
08. Kamalashila
09. Asanga (one of the Six Ornaments)
10. Vasubhandu (one of the Six Ornaments)
11. Dignaga (one of the Six Ornaments)
12. Dharmakirti (one of the Six Ornaments)
13. Haribhadra
14. Vimuktisena
15. Gunaprabha (one of the Two Supreme Ones)
16. Shakyaprabha (one of the Two Supreme Ones)
17. Atisha

Caption:
~
Lama Tsongkhapa - Life Story in 15 Thangkas

Chintamani Rosary Spreading the Buddhaâ€™s Teachings; Great Ocean of Benefit and Joy

A Method for Depicting the Sacred Biography of the Great Jetsun Tsongkhapa on Painted Cloth in One Hundred and Fifty-Three Parts

By Kunkhyen Jamyang Shepai Dorje

Continuation

Thangka 4:
â€¦
(12) In autumn Tsongkhapa accepted many offerings which had been sent from his birthplace. In Maldro Lhalung, he trained his mind in tantra under the guidance of Lama Sonam Dragpa. He stayed in strict retreat and studied a commentary on pramana called Treasury of Reasonings. Upon developing an extraordinary realization, tears streamed from his eyes and his hairs continuously stood on end.

To be continued, always on Tuesdays.

Translated by Ven. Tenzin Legtsok

Caption:
~
Praise of the Twelve Acts of the Buddha
by Jigme Lingpa

Continuation
â€¦
Through three incalculable aeons in samsaric existence,
You sought the meaningful, by binding all your thoughts
With the rope of accumulating merit and wisdom.
Then, beneath the bodhi tree, you put the mÄras to flight,
And attained enlightenment, as all the buddhas do.
On the ship of the three turnings of the Wheel of Dharma, you save
Beings who rush into saá¹ƒsÄraâ€™s bottomless and endless abyss,
And ferry them to the perfect levels of liberation and omniscience:
I bow to you in homage!
â€¦
To be continued

This is the word of Rigdzin Jigme Lingpa.

Download full text: https://www.lotsawahouse.org/tibetan-masters/jigme-lingpa/praise-twelve-acts-buddha

Thanks to: Rigpa Translations

The twelve great acts of Buddha Shakyamuni are:

1. The descent from Tushita, the Joyous pure land,
2. Entering the motherâ€™s womb,
3. Taking birth,
4. Becoming skilled in various arts,
5. Delighting in the company of royal consorts,
6. Developing renunciation and becoming ordained,
7. Practicing austerities for six years,
8. Proceeding to the foot of the Bodhi tree,
9. Overcoming Maraâ€™s hosts ,
10. Becoming fully enlightened,
11. Turning the wheel of Dharma and
12. Passing into Mahaparinirvana.

For further elaboration and information on the twelve deeds of the Buddha, see: Encyclopedia Buddhica Fall 2019 (https://encyclopediabuddhicaf19.andrewquintman.wescreates.wesleyan.edu/blog/t/the-twelve-acts/)

Caption:
This Saturday, June 8, senior student Ellen Webb will offer the dharma talk, followed by Q&A.

5:40 a.m. Zendo Opens
6:00-6:40 Zazen
6:40-6:50 Kinhin
6:50-7:20 Zazen
7:20-7:40 Service
7:40-8:30 Breakfast
8:30-8:45 Break
8:45-9:30 Work Practice
9:30-10:05 Zazen
10:05-10:15 Kinhin
10:15-11:15 Dharma Talk

Berkeley Zen Center also offers in-person zazen instruction every Saturday morning, from 8:40 to 9:10 a.m. Pacific. No need to sign up; all are welcome.

May all beings be well. May all beings be at peace. May all beings be free from suffering.

Caption:
We offer a wide variety of accommodations for your personal retreat at Crestone Mountain Zen Center. 

The Edge Cabin, our newest and most spacious private cabin, sits on the edge of the forest and canyon, offering stunning views of the ancient Crestone Peaks and the expansive San Luis Valley, a landscape that was once a massive lake.

From the secluded porch of the Edge Cabin, you can take in the vast valley, forest branches, and majestic peaks. The cabin is equipped with a kitchenette, toilet, tub, shower, desk, internet, queen bed, yoga and meditation space, and cozy chairs.

Find a home, a shelter, a sanctum in this shareable vastness. Step back, step in, and step within!

WISDOM EYES

The Eyes of Buddha is a symbol in Buddhist art representing the all-seeing eyes of the Buddha.

The Eyes of Buddha are often painted onto Tibetan stupas, and are found most commonly throughout Nepal. The symbol is typically painted onto all four sides at the top of the stupa, to symbolize the Buddhaâ€™s wisdom and ability to see all things in each of the four cardinal directions.

Caption:
BEYOND ACCEPTING OR REJECTING 

The open path is a matter of working purely with what is, of giving up altogether the fear that something may not work, that something may end in failure. One has to give up the paranoia that one might not fit into situations, that one might be rejected. One purely deals with life as it is.

ChÃ¶gyam Trungpa "Cutting Through Spiritual Materialism" 

You do not have to abandon worldly activities in order to attain effortless unconcern. You should know that worldly activities and effortless unconcern are not two different things, but if you keep thinking about rejection and grasping, you make them two.

HuiNeng (the 6th Zen Patriarch), translation by Thomas Cleary, Classics of Buddhism and Zen, Volume 1 

The next time you lose heart and you canâ€™t bear to experience what youâ€™re feeling, you might recall this instruction: change the way you see it and lean in. Instead of blaming our discomfort on outer circumstances or on our own weakness, we can choose to stay present and awake to our experience, not rejecting it, not grasping it, not buying the stories that we relentlessly tell ourselves. This is priceless advice that addresses the true cause of suffering â€” yours, mine, and that of all living beings.

Pema ChÃ¶dron, "Taking the Leap: Freeing Ourselves from Old Habits and Fears"

The Way is perfect like vast space
where nothing is lacking and nothing is in excess.
Indeed, it is due to our choosing to accept or reject
that we do not see the true nature of things.
Be serene in the oneness of things
and such erroneous views will disappear by themselves.

Sengcan (Third Zen Patriarch), Trans. Richard B. Clarke 

Since everything is but an apparition,
Perfect in being what it is,
Having nothing to do with good and bad,
Acceptance or rejection,
You might as well burst out laughing!

Longchenpa, Glimpse After Glimpse: Daily Reflections on Living and Dying"

Caption:
Dear Dharma Friends,
Thank you for your continued support and understanding of the dissemination effort of Soto Zen School.
This is 3rd time post regarding Noto peninsula in Ishikawa relief fund.
We extend our prays for the victims and their families and wish for their early recovery and restoration of life.
We appreciate it if you could kindly send checks to the Association of Soto Zen Buddhists so that we can transfer the amount to the Soto shu shumu-cho, Soto Zen Buddhism administrative headquarters office in Japan.
More than 100 Soto Zen temples affected by the disaster. We are sharing the photos of some temples.
We would appreciate it if you could help us raise relief funds with the support from your sangha and community members.
You can see more damages from this website. https://www.sotozen-net.jp/report/

ãƒ»Payment deadline: June 30th, 2024
ãƒ»Payment Method  1. Mailing cash or a checkã€€2. PayPal mailto:info@sotozen.us
 *Check (payable to Association of Soto Zen Buddhists)
 Mailing Address: 123 South Hewitt St, Los Angeles, CA 90012

In Gassho,

Caption:
Las instituciones deben desmantelar los discursos hegemÃ³nicos que perpetÃºan la exclusiÃ³n y el estigma. Esto implica una transformaciÃ³n radical de las polÃ­ticas y prÃ¡cticas educativas, legales y mediÃ¡ticas. Las escuelas deben convertirse en espacios donde la diversidad no solo se tolere, sino que se celebre y se integre como parte fundamental del proceso educativo. Las leyes deben reflejar un compromiso inquebrantable con la igualdad y la justicia, asegurando que ningÃºn individuo sea marginado o discriminado. Los medios de comunicaciÃ³n, por su parte, tienen la responsabilidad de representar de manera justa y digna a todas las identidades, desafiando los estereotipos y promoviendo narrativas inclusivas.

Caption: "Nonfabrication is a state of shamatha meditation that is free from any conceptual labeling. At this stage, there is no process of labeling our experience as one thing or another, such as thoughts of "resting" or "not resting" or "This is Mahamudra shamatha" or "This is not Mahamudra shamatha." We must be totally free from these fabrications. When we rest in that state of mind, there is a great sense of freedom."\n-Dzogchen Ponlop Rinpoche | June 7th | https://bit.ly/nsi24mmm

The Blue Temple, or Wat Rong Suea Ten, is a modern Buddhist temple in Chiang Rai, Thailand. Known for its striking blue and gold color scheme, it was designed by Putha Kabkaew, a student of the artist who created the White Temple. The temple's interior features intricate murals and a large white Buddha statue. Opened in 2016, the Blue Temple blends traditional Thai temple architecture with contemporary artistic elements.  #jeffreyrosenkrantz #postcard #postcardprint #thailand #chiangrai #watrongsueaten #bluetemple #buddhism #artexhibit #uniquearchitecture #travel #photos  https://travel.jeffreyrosenkrantz.com/photos/chiang-rai-blue-temple

Caption:
At a time when there is so much division, isolation and separateness, itâ€™s more important than ever to enhance our emotional connection with others. 

Weâ€™re excited to announce that on Sunday 9th June David will be leading a Joyful Heart day retreat at Jamyang Buddhist Centre in London to explore the cultivation of the heart and mind through the practices of the Four Immeasurables. The teachings will be based upon Lama Alanâ€™s book, Four Immeasurables: Practices to Open the Heart.

Explore the transformational practices of the Four Immeasurables - loving-kindness, compassion, empathetic joy and equanimity
Learn techniques that help you connect with others and overcome feelings of isolation.
Engage in meditations that open the heart and promote inner and outer harmony.
Learn how to increase understanding and empathy towards those who challenge us.
Share and learn with like-minded friends in group discussions.

Canâ€™t join in person? You can access the teachings online as well!

Caption:
When the master makes a mistake, he realizes it. Having realized it, he admits it. Having admitted it, he corrects it. He doesnâ€™t get offended by the ones who point out his faults. Instead, he treats them as his generous teachers. He catches himself when heâ€™s not giving his best, and then he fixes it. He treats every faulty realization as an opportunity to increase self-awareness and become better, not an excuse to feel down.

Caption:
Meditation has been around for thousands of years. Early meditation was to help deepen understanding of the sacred and mystical forces of life. 

For some, meditation is most often used to relax and lower stress.

It is great that there is now scientific research into meditation to offer the physicalist explanations that so many modern minds want. 

But in a Buddhist context we can still have the spiritual aspects that allow for insight, connection and steer us away from delusion. 

There are many different reasons why people choose to learn meditation.  Many come to the centre initially for stress relief. 

But thereâ€™s more to it than that! 

During meditation, you focus on one thing. You get rid of the stream of thoughts that may be crowding your mind and causing stress. 

This process can lead to better physical and emotional well-being.

Caption:
"When all my earlier ways of grasping had faded away, I came to rest in the spontaneous vastness of the ever-pure ground of being. In that moment, everything that arose as the creative expressions of that ground dissolved naturally back into that same expanse.

This primordial ground- together with its creative expressions, free of modification, antidote, meditation practice, memory, grasping, and identification-is called path pristine awareness.

This ultimate reality is most easily seen in the absence of mental activity. As hopes, fears, negation, and affirmation dissolve into absolute space, their quiescence reveals the self-emergent primordial consciousness, the timeless mode of the great dharmakÄya, free of all extremes, partiality, going, and coming.

Know that all appearances are the creative expressions of pristine awareness; they slip back into the essential nature, dissolving into the primordial womb like waves naturally subside back into the ocean..."

from "  Heart of the Great Perfection: Dudjom Lingpa's Visions of the Great Perfection, Vol. 1 " 
by B. Alan Wallace

Caption:

ğŸª· Offering to the Spiritual Guide, 6:30pm

Every day we remember the extraordinary kindness of Venerable Geshe-la, our Root Guru and Founder of the New Kadampa Tradition. But on the auspicious day June 4 on Venerable Geshe-laâ€™s birthday, at Kadampa centers around the world, with minds of rejoicing and gratitude, we offer him our faith through using the special prayer Request to the Holy Spiritual Guide Venerable Geshe Kelsang Gyatso from his Faithful Disciples and collecting our Guruâ€™s name mantra in a one-day retreat. Everyone is welcome to take part.

Schedule
Tuesday, June 4th
Session 1: 9am-10:30am
Session 2: 11:30am-1:00pm
Session 3: 3pm-4:30pm

Caption:
Kiyomizudera temple in the wooded hills east of Kyoto famous for â€œjump off the stage at Kiyomizuâ€ expression.

The expression â€œto jump off the stage at Kiyomizuâ€ is the Japanese equivalent of the English expression â€œto take the plungeâ€. This refers to an Edo-period tradition that held that if one survived a 13-meter (43-foot) jump from the stage, oneâ€™s wish would be granted. During the Edo period, 234 jumps were recorded, and of the jumpers, 85.4 per cent survived. The practice was prohibited in 1872.

Caption:
The Ten Stages of Spiritual Cow-Herding
5: Herding the Cow

When a thought moves, another follows, and then anotherâ€¦ There is thus awakened an endless train of thoughts. Through enlightenment all this turns into truth; but falsehood asserts itself when confusion prevails. Things oppress us not because of an objective world, but because of a self-deceiving mind. Do not get the nose-string loose; hold it tight, and allow yourself no indulgence

Never let yourself be separated from the whip and the tether,
Lest you should wander away into a world of defilement:
When she is properly tended, she will grow pure and docile,
Even without chain, nothing binding, she will by herself follow you.

Caption:
Early 2024 we met for the last EnsÅ for the time being. EnsÅ was an online sharing and practice circle led by people from the sangha â­•ï¸. It was a great experience to regularly, once a month host these sessions and to explore various forms of practices, like shaking, yoga asana, embodiment practices and guided meditations and so on. We want to thank the community for their help in the creation of a space for us all to share and experience new forms of practices.

Thank you to everyone who participated and also to the last remaining three of the original five founders: @annkn.aut @giacomosantiagorogado and @internalpractice pictured here in one of our organisational meetings. Thank you also to Claudia and Christina for their initial support and the dedication to create this community concept.

We might do another instalment of this at some point, maybe then in-person. Would you join?

Caption:
Sanghadana Lunch Offering and Patidana Transference of Merits from Jayathilake Family of California.

In Singalovada Sutta, Buddha taught: 
"In five ways, young householder, a child should minister to his parents as the East: 
(i) Having supported me I shall support them, 
(ii) I shall do their duties, 
(iii) I shall keep the family tradition, 
(iv) I shall make myself worthy of my inheritance, 
(v) furthermore I shall offer alms in honor of my departed relatives.

Caption:
Was wÃ¤re, wenn alle Taten sofort ihre Karma-Wirkung verursachen wÃ¼rden und nicht erst im nÃ¤chsten Leben? Dieses Gedankenexperiment spielt der Autor auf sehr unterhaltsamen Weise in seinem Roman Â»Instant KarmaÂ« durch.

Ich bin mit relativ wenigen Erwartungen an das Buch herangegangen. Ich hatte sogar sogar befÃ¼rchtet, dass es allzu belehrend werden kÃ¶nnte. TatsÃ¤chlich aber regt der Inhalt zwar zum Nachdenken an, kann jedoch gleichzeitig sehr gut unterhalten.

Das Cover ist zwar etwas nichtssagend, aber stimmungsvoll. Besonders die Farbgebung und der feste Einband kÃ¶nnen Ã¼berzeugen. 

Das besondere an dem Buch ist, dass wir vielen verschiedenen Charakteren folgen. Diese werden gut dargestellt, sodass man sich schnell in sie hineinversetzen kann. Toll finde ich dabei auch, wie unterschiedlich die Personen sind und somit fÃ¼r fast jeden Leser Bezugspunkte bieten. 

Dabei werden die einzelnen Geschichten zu einer groÃŸen verwoben und hÃ¤ngen alle indirekt, teils auch direkt, miteinander zusammen. Dabei wird nie das Thema Â»KarmaÂ« aus dem Blick verloren. 

Der Schreibstil ist auf jeden Fall sehr angenehm. Die Szenerien werden zwar nicht unbedingt besonders bildlich beschrieben, aber dafÃ¼r liegt der Fokus mehr auf der Geschichte. Die Kapitel sind meist kurz und dadurch sehr kurzweilig. Zudem eignet sich das Buch durch seinen Aufbau gut, um nur mal zwischendurch zu lesen.

Insgesamt hat das Buch auf jeden Fall einiges zu bieten. Mal bringt es einem zum Lachen, andermal regt es zum Nachdenken an. Insgesamt handelt es sich auf jeden Fall um eine LektÃ¼re, die man zwar nebenbei lesen kann, aber dennoch auch lÃ¤nger auf sich wirken lassen sollte. Zudem eignet sich das Buch auch gut fÃ¼r Einsteiger und Interessierte an der Materie Â»KarmaÂ«, da die wichtigsten Elemente nicht nur theoretisch, sondern auch sehr praktisch erklÃ¤rt werden.

Caption:
Tomorrow, June 4th, everyone is welcome to take part in CELEBRATING VENERABLE GESHE KELSANG GYATSO RINPOCHE
A special day of retreat in the meditation room at Atisha KMC. 

Every day we remember the extraordinary kindness of Venerable Geshe-la, our Root Guru and Founder of the New Kadampa Tradition.
But on the auspicious day June 4 (Turning the Wheel of Dharma Day), at Kadampa centres around the world, with minds of rejoicing and gratitude, we offer him our faith through using the special prayer Request to the Holy Spiritual Guide Venerable Geshe Kelsang Gyatso from his Faithful Disciples and collecting our Guruâ€™s name mantra in a one-day retreat.

Caption:
The only true elegance is vulnerability.

Elegance means appreciating things as they are. 
There is a sense of delight and of fearlessness. 
You are not fearful of dark corners. 
If there are any dark, mysterious corners, 
black and confusing, 
you override them with your glory, 
your sense of beauty, 
your sense of cleanness, 
your feeling of being regal. 

Because you can override fearlfulness in this way, 
tantra, 
or the highest stage in Tibetan Buddhist practice, 
is known as the king of all the stages on the path. 
You take an attitude of 
having perfectly complete 
and very rich basic sanity.

â€”ChÃ¶gyam Trungpa Rinpoche

Caption:
If you really wish to know me â€¦
Then do not focus on other things
for a moment, and find that which
can not change within yourself. It is not found in ones clothes , name, opinions, beliefs, or identity that one has
chosen to play.
I am â€¦ ever here â€¦
I am â€¦ the unchanging one â€¦
reflecting your own unchangeable Self.

â€œThere are 3 things I donâ€™t envyâ€

One, I donâ€™t envy magical power. Many people gave me leaf, stone, saying they went to India or Tibet, meditated on Buddha statue, suddenly got peace of mind and a leaf fell on their head. What am I supposed to do with that?

Second, I donâ€™t envy people try to look for inspiration outside. You pay 8000 dollars to attend yoga or samadhi seminar, when come out, youâ€™re the same person. We have all goodness of human being within. Why do we look for that outside? Some quotes give us tenderness in our mind. Itâ€™s because the author realized something in their mind, not from outside.

Third, as Buddhist practitioner, I donâ€™t envy people practise riding on excitement. Many people practise or do retreat when excited. When not excited, everything is forgotten. What about continuity, stability, single minded? We focus so much on external, materialist things. This includes your devotion to teacher. You demand teacher should think, do what you like. And we extremely attach to the outer form of teacher, instead of looking at inner qualities.

To be born as human being, we have and should cherish our immeasurable inner qualities - pure goodness, genuineness. But when look within, we are frightened with so many emotions on surface, then tell ourselves "I donâ€™t want to look any more. Itâ€™s too much." 

â€” Dilgo Khyentse Yangsi Rinpoche

Source ğŸ™ Lepus Oiostolus ğŸŒ·

Caption:
ONE WEEK FROM TODAY! 

Join us next Monday at 7:00pm for our special event with Kadam Morten: How Love Solves Your Problems.

Offered in person (for everyone) and online (for members only) 

Nurturing our innate potential for love â€“ a mind of truly cherishing others â€“ is the best thing we can do for ourself and for others. Buddha called the mind of love "the great protector" because it protects us from unhappiness and gives us the internal openness and flexibility to deal skillfully with all the various difficult situations we encounter.

Nurturing love in our heart heals our relationship with ourself, our family and friends, and, ultimately, our world. We may think this sounds idealistic but in truth itâ€™s very practical. Buddha taught special methods whereby in meditation we learn to tune into our own capacity for love, to nurture it and expand it, opening it to more and more people (and animals!). In this series Kadam Morten will guide us in these heart enriching meditations and explain how we can apply them to solving the various problems in our lives.

Everyone welcome.

Learn more and register at: https://meditationinnewyork.org/how-love-solves-your-problems/

Caption:
Alright body! You got 5 days to get in gear and get well!! Next week is a busy week with two trips to NYC for the reading and a work event. 

This last week has been extremely difficult. Iâ€™ve been dealing with a serious gout attack. My foot has been in constant pain and has drained me badly, physically and mentally. The pain has been so intense I canâ€™t meditate. I canâ€™t swim, kicking my foot in water would be excruciating. Yesterday, I happened to have a full day outside and frankly, I overdid it. I came home early and started to feel feverish. I had chills throughout the night and today my disposition is just very weak. How I would love to be in bed all day but my boss is away on vacation and I have to keep the company going. Ughâ€¦â€¦.

I need to find ways to strengthen my immune system and my energy levels. After the show in March I developed a fever. My last trip to NYC in April I came back and threw my back out. And now this bout stuck has really depleted me. This canâ€™t continue. I would be appreciative of any advice people have for strengthening their internal health. (@tullyjohns any advice???)

Meanwhile, Iâ€™m just here. Surviving and working. Thatâ€™s about it today. And yeah, I realize this Springsteen song isnâ€™t about being sick, but itâ€™s kinda close to what Iâ€™m feelingâ€¦

Caption:
Kijk ğŸ‘€ naar de voeten van Butsuzo.
Beelden van Boeddha's en bodhisattva's die in Japan voorkomen, zijn meestal blootsvoets.ğŸ¦¶
Het dragen van schoenen of laarzen wordt vaak gezien bij beelden van de hemelse goden (Deva godheid).

Look at the feet of Butsuzo.
The images of Tathagatas and Bodhisattvas in Japan are usually barefoot.
Wearing shoes or boots is often seen in the statues of the heavenly deities.

Buddhism â˜¸ï¸.

The portrait at the extreme right is of King Ashoka.

Following the violent Kalinga battle, which claimed the lives of thousands, he went to a nearby village and observed widows, orphans, and helpless parents of the murdered troops. That's when he felt incredibly sad and chose to convert to Buddhism for eternal peace.

Caption:
Chiang Mai, Thailand ğŸ‡¹ğŸ‡­ Elephant Sanctuary ğŸ˜ğŸ˜
â€¢
The elephants in Thailand will always have a special place in my heart â™¥ï¸
â€¢
Hereâ€™s a little back history-
â€¢
Thailand is a majority Buddhist country and elephants are portrayed as sacred animals from their special symbolism in the practice of Buddhism. In Thailand elephants were very important in battle, with kings mounted on elephants fighting the Burmese to defend Thailand on many occasions. Before the modern era of war machines, elephants were heavily utilized by armies across Asia. Elephants in Thailand are protected by several laws and conservation efforts. The Asian elephants are an endangered species.  Between 3100 and 3600 can be found in 69 protected areas in Thailand. They can live up to 80 years. 
â€¢

Caption:
For millennia, humanity has gazed at the stars and pondered the nature of reality. Different religions have offered profound and varied answers to this fundamental question. While their details may differ, a fascinating common thread emerges when we examine these diverse perspectives. 

Duality and Monism: Two Sides of the Coin

Many religions fall into two broad categories regarding reality: dualistic and monistic. Dualistic religions, like Zoroastrianism and some forms of Christianity, posit the existence of two fundamental realities - a material world and a spiritual world, often locked in opposition. Good versus evil, light versus darkness - these are expressions of this duality.

Monistic religions, such as Hinduism and Buddhism, propose a single, unified reality. Hinduism, with its concept of Brahman, the ultimate reality underlying all existence, emphasizes the interconnectedness of everything. Similarly, Buddhism views reality as a web of interdependent phenomena, arising and dissolving in a ceaseless flow.

Beyond Duality and Monism: The Journey Within

Some religions, like Judaism and Islam, transcend this binary. Judaism emphasizes a covenant relationship between God and humanity, grounding reality in a divine presence within creation. Islam, with its concept of tawhid (oneness of God), proposes a single, all-encompassing reality, with God as the ultimate source and sustainer.

The Shared Human Experience: A Common Thread

Despite these differences, a core theme connects these religions: the search for meaning and purpose within the vastness of existence. Most religions offer a path or practice to connect with what they consider the ultimate reality, be it through faith, devotion, or ethical living. This pursuit, a quest for transcendence, is a universal human experience.

Conclusion: A Tapestry of Belief

The nature of reality, as viewed by different religions, is like a rich tapestry woven with diverse threads. Duality and monism, the material and the spiritual, intertwine to create a profound sense of wonder and possibility. (Continued in pinned comments..)

The transfer of merit is  continuous and inexhaustible.

Here we are hanging with Sandra Oh post-performance of a powerful play sheâ€™s starring in, The Welkin. Sandra, how can you even stand up straight after putting out such huge emotional energy during more than two hours of high-intensity drama? 

If you are anywhere near New York, donâ€™t miss this play! It is one of the best either of us have ever seen, so timely at this time in our countryâ€™s history. 

The plot: 
In rural England, 1759, as the country awaits the return of Halleyâ€™s comet, a young woman is sentenced to death. When she tries to escape the noose by claiming she is pregnant, twelve ordinary women are gathered to decide whether she is telling the truth.

Caption: Taking care of a Butsudan, or altar space is an important part of practicing Buddha-dharma. This space is where we make offerings, perform rituals, chant sutras, practice the six paramita, and connect with the ever present nature of awakening. The altar can be as elaborate or as simple as needed. Daily interaction is essential to the meaning of the altar as a place of practice. Just a small daily gesture of offering incense, tea, water, flowers, or fruit puts the intention of raising the bodhi mind with gratitude for the teaching. #butsudan#buddha#buddhism#zazen#mandala#yakushinyorai#medicinebuddha#bhaisajyaguru#shakyamuni#gautamabuddha#mantra#shingon#tendaishu#åç¦…#ä»æ•™#ä»å£‡#è–¬å¸«å¦‚æ¥#é‡ˆè¿¦å¦‚æ¥#çœŸè¨€#å¤©å°å®—#ä½›#ä»#æ³•#dharma#ãƒãƒ³ãƒ€ãƒ©

Caption:
Wisst Ihr schon, wie Ihr bei den Europawahlen abstimmen wollt?

Vielleicht hilft es Euch ja bei Eurer Entscheidung, wenn Ihr die Positionen der Parteien zu Tibet kennt.

ICT hat im Vorfeld der Wahlen gemeinsam mit der Tibet Initiative Deutschland den Parteien insgesamt acht Fragen gestellt. Caption:
Iâ€™ll discuss this in more detail in my next post, including the relevance/importance of learning to let the external world (including your accumulations) be an extension of the most free part of you (i.e. what does it mean to desire, build, and accumulate things in a way that is already free and imbued with the energy of letting go), as well as the importance of not bypassing patterns of â€œwantingâ€ because you think you should be spiritual and want not.

This topic opens up a can of worms, so be patient and weâ€™ll get into it in the next video.

For now, just let it impact you. And notice HOW it impacts youâ€¦ 

Do you like and agree with it because it makes you feel comfortable with the pain of not having what you want? (thatâ€™s not the freedom or wisdom this post is inviting) 

Do you dislike and disagree with it because it triggers the egoic parts of you that want what they want and feel threatened by the idea of not getting it? (thatâ€™s worth paying to)

Weâ€™ll discuss in more detail, but feel free to share any thoughts below of what this brings up for you.

Karma Triyana Dharmachakra is a Tibetan Buddhist monastery in Woodstock, New York, which serves as the North American seat of the 17th Gyalwa Karmapa, head of the 900 year old Karma Kagyu Buddhist lineage. It looks like maybe today itâ€™s someoneâ€™s birthday at the temple. We were there for just a few minutes and must have been early for the party. Caption:
Part of the tour was to stop at the holy, high-altitude freshwater lake, Manasarovar @4500m's. It wasn't exactly around the corner, but a bum numbing 10+hr drive from Kyirong far into Western Tibet. 

It's a long journey, yes, but the stunning scenery makes up for it. The arid, vast, desert landscape captives, sky feels low (average altitude of Tibetan Plateau is +/- 4500m's), and the empty, ready-built villages add to the mysteriousness of this remote land. 

And then the colours. The traditional dresses and jewellery sparkle with a multitude of colours,Â  the sky is clear blue, and even our guesthouse walls delighted us with a combination of psychedelic shapes and colours.

Having heard and dreamed about Lake Manasarovar and Mt Kailas for years, it was a pretty special moment and feeling to actually see both for the first time, with your own eyes. Kailas was very awe-inspiring, and the tranquillity of Manasarovar was beautiful,Â  meditational even. We managed to spend a bit of time on its shores, deep on our thoughts soaking up the spiritual energy.

This was the centre of the world or universe for many believers, and you could see why. There was something magical and powerful about this place, having made thousands of pilgrims flock to its shores or to the base of the mountain for centuries. Despite different religions and beliefs, they all came united at this very same place on Earth.

With roomies @maja_pien_kos and Chris.

Caption:
Allen Ginsberg was born on this day in Newark New Jersey, 98 years ago! 

Born in this world
You got to suffer
Everything changes
You got no soul

Try to be gay
Ignorant happy
You get the blues
You eat jellyroll

There is one Way
You take the high road
In your big Wheel
8 steps you fly

Look at the View
Right to horizon
Talk to the sky
Act like you talk

Work like the sun
Shine in your heaven
See what you done
Come down & walk

Sit you sit down
Breathe when you breathe
Lie downÂ  Â  you lie down
Walk where you walk

Talk when you talk
Cry when you cry
Lie downÂ  Â  you lie down
Die when you die

Look when you look
Hear what you hear
Taste what you tasteÂ  Â  here
Smell what you smell

Touch what you touch
Think what you think
Let go Let it goÂ  Â  Slow
Earth Heaven & Hell

Die when you die
Die when you die
Lie downÂ  Â  you lie down
Die when you die

New York, Subway, October 17, 1975

Gospel Noble Truths 
(The Four Noble Truths sung in a Blues form)
Mind Breaths: Poems 1972-1977, City Lights SF 1978
Photo: Steve Dickenson, with Allenâ€™s camera, Seattle September 1, 1991

Caption:
Tonight we begin a new course: Experience Love Daily.
It is a prevailing notion that in order for us to be happy we must receive love from others. What if this conception is wrong? What if in order for us to be happy we must give love to others? In this way they naturally wish to give love to us. The point is, we must give in order to receive. If we only try to take the love of others our relationships will falter, remain unsatisfactory and inharmonious. Discover the truth of this supposition. 

Tonight's class: Recognizing the Kindness of Others
7:30 - 9 PM

EVERYONE WELCOME

Caption:
"Towards Buddhas and all beings, we should have equal reverence. In whichever sadhana, or practice, we perform, immediately after taking refuge, we generate the attitude of Bodhichitta, gaining the wisdom and compassion to be of benefit. From that moment on, other beings become the support for our practice. We may thus appreciate their great significance. For those who wish to attain enlightenment, the Buddhas and all other sentient beings have equal kindness."

- Kyabje Dilgo Khyentse Rinpoche

Caption:
Upcoming online course
ğŸ‘† CLICK PROGRAM CALENDAR IN THE BIO TO LEARN MORE

Join Dawn Haney and Nina Herzog for this weekly online program. By welcoming and gathering fat-identified people into community to explore the four noble truths of Buddhism, we hope to create new frameworks for understanding and practicing (fat) liberation. 

We will revisit basic Buddhist concepts â€“ the three poisons of greed, hatred, and delusion; the three factors of existence of suffering, identity, and change; and the three refuges of Buddha, Dharma, and Sangha â€“ dropping any interference from diet culture and drawing instead from kindness and compassion for our embodiment, as it is. In this new program, we will re-construct Buddhist practices of â€œembodimentâ€ to make sense in our own fat bodies.

No.3
Sin-me 
Nishi-mera 
15-16th century 
Ex Yufuin-Kuuso-no-mori Museum collection 

Sin-me was dedicated to shrines as a horse to be ridden by gods. As time went by, wooden carved horses were used instead of real horses, and eventually, board-shaped horses came into use, which became ema (votive tablets with horse paintings).
Although this work is decayed and missing its legs, it still looks divine and has not lost its spirit of carrying the gods on its back. Even if it is a fragment. Isn't that what â€œfaithâ€ is all about?

Caption:
Many ask questions about what is Ambedkarism. 
Some are about to get it erased. One should be very cautious about this. One must realise Instragram trending posts is not Ambedkarism. Here we have attempted to Answer to these students of Instagram University. 
Reference: BAWS Vol. 17, part 3 p. 503

For helping with the reference.

About the lotus seed MalağŸª·
*
*
The lotus flower is a highly revered and symbolic flower in Buddhism, as it represents purity and enlightenment. Despite growing in muddy waters, the lotus flower blooms beautifully without being tainted, symbolizing the ability to rise above oneâ€˜s circumstances. The lotus seed also carries this symbolic meaning, representing spiritual growth and inner peace.

The spiritual practice of using lotus seeds can help cultivate inner peace, self-awareness, and a deeper understanding of the universe. They also convey a sense of tranquility and calmness.

Therefore, the lotus flower and lotus seeds hold immense symbolic significance in Buddhism, representing purification, enlightenment, and spiritual growth.

Moreover, the lotus flower promotes feelings of serenity and peace. Its ability to rise above the challenges of its environment can be a source of comfort and inspiration to those struggling with anxiety. Lotus seed beads are known to cleanse negative energy, enhance focus, and foster a sense of well-being.

Wearing your Lotus Seed mala or bracelet throughout the day serves as a reminder of your intentions and goals. Focusing on the present moment by touching the beads can help distract from anxious thoughts as well as provide a reminder of the lotus flowerâ€™s journey, offering a sense of strength and hope.

Caption:
"Vipassana: Unlocking the Mysteries of the Mind" by Vineet and Pratibha is a thoughtful and accessible guide to the ancient practice of Vipassana meditation. The authors, drawing from their personal journeys, demystify this profound technique with clarity and simplicity, making it a valuable resource for beginners. Their practical advice, step-by-step instructions, and relatable anecdotes set this book apart, offering readers an engaging and authentic introduction to mindfulness and self-awareness.

A significant focus of the book is the transformative power of the 10-day Vipassana retreat, which is essential for deepening meditation practice. These retreats involve complete silence and intense meditation, allowing participants to achieve a profound level of self-awareness and mental clarity. However, some readers might find certain sections of the book repetitive, as the authors reiterate key points to reinforce their importance. I have taken my own sweet time to grasp the content of the book as it is difficult to live with self and hence, this reading in itself was a different experience.

Overall, "Vipassana: Unlocking the Mysteries of the Mind" is a commendable introduction to Vipassana meditation. Despite minor issues with repetitive content, the book's clear explanations and practical guidance make it a worthwhile read. Vineet and Pratibha provide a comprehensive and inspiring look at a practice that has the potential to profoundly transform oneâ€™s life.

It fosters mindfulness, concentration, and wisdom, empowering the mind to navigate daily life, detach from sensations, enhance self-esteem, let go of suffering, and access inner happiness. This leads to achieving freedom in the present moment.

Caption:
In the Buddhist context, the sound of the gong is considered sacred.

It is used to mark the beginning and end of meditation sessions, to signal meal times in monasteries, and to call monks to prayer.

The deep, resonant sound of the gong creates an atmosphere of peace and introspection, helping practitioners to focus their minds and enter a state of deep meditation.

Caption:
Mani stones resembling tablets carved out of the sides of rock formations are in locations throughout the Nepali areas of the Himalayas.
Prayer flags flutter around every where.
Prayer wheels are in every corner of every village.

Om Mani Padme Hum.
Hail to the Jewel in the Lotus.
It is said that you should not seek for Buddhahood outside of yourself; the substances for the achievement of Buddhahood are within.â€

Caption:
Dengan demikian ia merenung tentang tubuhnya dengan melihatnya ke dalam, melihatnya dari luar dan melihatnya dari sudut kedua-duanya secara bergantian.

Atau ia berdiam dalam perenungan tentang apa yang dapat menimbulkan tubuh ini, atau â€¦ berdiam dalam perenungan tentang timbulnya dan lenyapnya kembali tubuh ini secara bergantian.

Dan ia berpikir: â€˜Ini adalah sebuah tubuhâ€™, dan perhatiannya itu diberikan hanya sampai pada tingkat menyadari, hanya sebagai pengenalan belaka; dan ia meneruskan perenungannya dengan tidak menggantungkan diri atau melekat kepada tubuhnya itu. Itulah yang harus dilakukan oleh seorang bhikkhu yang berdiam dalam perenungan dengan perhatian benar terhadap tubuhnya.

We are pleased to share a news article from yesterday's Ceylon Today newspaper in Sri Lanka ğŸ‡±ğŸ‡°, which highlights the significant work our teachers are conducting in Australia. True to our motto at 'Ministry of Nirvana', "Building a happier Australia ğŸ‡¦ğŸ‡º," we are committed towards spreading the Buddhaâ€™s teachings and enhancing mental well-being in the Australian and New Zealand ğŸ‡³ğŸ‡¿ communities. ğŸŒ¿

The article details our services, which focuses on mindful awareness workshops to help manage stress, anxiety and depression emphasizing mental health as our priority. Our venerable monks who are well-versed in Buddhist philosophy, offer counseling sessions providing support and guidance to those in need.

If you know someone who needs help managing mental health challenges, please reach out to us and share this message with your loved ones and encourage them to participate in our programs.

Caption: Although the writing is not verbatim mine, enough of the word choice is, and enough of the smaller phrases are. And those were taken from a typed file later compromised because my neighbors were selling my IP address, as was stated, or had some kind of involvement otherwise. This is what presaged the reminders of all of the commercials that were taken from private conversation. And the response seems to be kind of the norm for many people. It doesn't matter, for many, how someone might acquire the content they want to sell, so long as it isn't itself copyrighted. The common sense  of it is easy to ascertain. If you can't answer "Yes" when someone asks, "Is this yours?" then you can't say otherwise.\n\n#rap #hiphop #judaism #logic #ethics #politics #philosophy #mathematics #settheory #deconstruction #buddhism #phenomenology #existentialism #numbertheory #metaphysics #epistemology #meta #writing #poetry #story #flashfiction #nonfiction #postmodern #editorial #opinion #history

Caption:
The Avukana Buddha statue is a magnificent rock carving of a standing Buddha. This statue, which is a marvel of human creativity and artistry, is situated in the North Central Province of Sri Lanka, approximately 175 kilometres from Colombo at Avukana, close to Kekirawa. In the fifth century, under King Dhatusena's rule, Avukana was constructed.

Caption: The Tiger Cave Temple l à¸§à¸±à¸”à¸–à¹‰à¸³à¹€à¸ªà¸·à¸­ l is known for the tiger paw prints in the cave, tall Buddha statues and the strenuous flight of stairs to reach the summit. The temple is a Thai Buddhist meditation center and also has places of archaeological and historical significance. Examples of these historical attractions are stone tools, pottery shards, and molded Buddha footprints. At the top of the mountain there is a large golden Buddha statue. This statue, other temple buildings, and much of Krabi town can be seen from shrine at the top of the stairs.\n\n#thaisacredart #thai #thailand #thai #bangkok #buddha #buddhism #temple #menfashion #menwithstyle #muaythai #thaiboxing #tattoo #æ³°å›½ #kingpower #talisman #goodluck #rich #contemporaryart

Caption:
Join us in the Prayer Room as Khenpo Karze offers a Dharma banquet of teachings and a monthly Q&A at KPC.

Khenpo Karze teaches at 7:30pm on the 1st and 3rd Wednesdays, with a Q&A on the 4th Wednesday of every month. 

Knowledgeable, cheerful, open and delighted to engage with westerners, Khenpo Karze offers his wisdom from years of study at Namdroling in India. 

If you can't attend in person, join us on Zoom (link provided at registration). Register for a monthly class subscription or one class at a time. Link in bio.

Please be sure to select â€œMake this a monthly donationâ€ when signing up for the monthly subscription.

Caption:
Itâ€™s a big week at Meditation in Niagara! We have three meditation classes starting. 

Monday Joanna starts  a new set of classes called Developing True Confidence. 

Tuesday evening classes with Michelle return and this weekâ€™s class falls on Turning the Wheel of Dharma day.  Michelle will be teaching a class on Buddhas teachings for this modern time. 

Overcoming Anxiety is the topic of the classes starting this Thursday also with our wonderful teacher Joanna. 

Everybody Welcome!

Link in bio for all the details.

Master Jun Hong Lu â€“ Xin Ling Fa Men
ã…¤ã…¤
ğŸ™Orang yang ingin mengubah hidupnya harus belajar mengatasi dendam di hatinya, mengatasi kekhawatirannya, mengatasi perasaan penderitaannya, dan membiarkan hatinya  dapat menyambut cahaya.
Karena kita datang ke duniawi, kita tidak membawa  apa apa, ketika mati juga tidak bisa membawa apa apa, kita tidak ingin serakah terhadap segala sesuatu di dunia ini, menggunakan hati yang baik hidup didunia ini dengan baik,  Dalam masyarakat saat ini, 
Masih belum ada penyakit, tidak ada bencana alam atau bencana akibat ulah manusia. Ini sudah merupakan berkah. 
Kita harus berpuas hati dan bahagia.

Caption:
ğŸ•Œâœ¨ In a temple, worshippers seek the Buddha's gaze; in a museum, the Buddha is the object of the visitor's gaze. This paradox highlights the 'musealization' of living traditions.

ğŸ” For insights into musealization, heritage, and society, join INSTUCEN TRUST's  Allan Oscar Ritchie and Raamesh Gowri Raghavan for an exploration!!

ğŸ—ºï¸ Part 1: Walk through the evolution of Buddhism and major sculptural schools, interacting with artefacts.
ğŸ’¬ Part 2: Discuss the museum's role (as a colonialist-nationalist construct) in relation to living religions like Buddhism and Jainism, and the paradoxes in heritage conservation.

ğŸ“… Date: 9th June 2024
â° Time:  2 p.m. to 5 p.m. I.S.T
ğŸ’°. Fees : Rs. 800/-
ğŸ“ Location: CSMVS Buddhist and Tibetan Galleries
 
For more information, please click the link in our bio ğŸ”—

Caption:
Ladakh is a union territory of India but it feels like a world of it's own. It is known for it's rich cultural heritage, Tibetan Buddhist monasteries, and breathtaking landscapes.

The capital of the region - Leh - is situated at an altitude of roughly 3500m above sea-level, giving it a cold desert climate. It is nestled in the Indus River valley and surrounded by the stunning and peaceful Himalayan mountains ğŸ—»

After months of heat and humidity, I welcomed the cold weather ğŸ¤­ Being from England, it felt like a taste of home to wrap up in layers, and this wooly headband was perfect on days I wanted to tie my dreadlocks up!

Caption:
We speak of wisdom and concentration as separate things, but in essence they are one and the same. They arise from the same place but take different directions. Itâ€™s like a mango. A mango is first small and green. It then grows larger and larger until it is ripe. The small mango, the large one and the ripe one are the same mango, not different mangoes. Only its conditions have changed. In Dhamma practice, one condition is called concentration, and the later condition is called wisdom, but in 
actuality samadhi and panna are both the same thing, just like the mango.
(Ajahn Chah)

Caption:
â€œPeople may have been good to you, but itâ€™s not the case that they always will be. The human mind is very changeable, and they could change without notice. You canâ€™t rely on their goodness as your nourishment. Youâ€™ve got to learn how to take as your nourishment whatever goodness you can give rise to in yourself.

This is where goodwill [mettÄ] is very important. If, when youâ€™re not wishing any harm on anybody, harm does come to you, youâ€™re not going to feel guilty or that somehow it was a punishment for your unskillful attitude. You can just chalk it up to past kamma and leave it at that. Itâ€™s a much cleaner and more bearable way of thinking.â€

~ Thanissaro Bhikkhu â€œUnsentimental Goodwillâ€

Caption:
Super Cub Ã— Seogwangsa

The intial building of Seogwang Temple in Wimi was erected in 1961, after Seunim Sugyeong [ğ˜´ğ˜¦ğ˜¶ğ˜¯ğ˜ªğ˜® is a title for a Buddhist monk] prepared the land and built a thatched-roof building with donations from Bodhisattva Go Myeong-sim (Gong Deok-hwa), the founder of what was then, it seems, a smaller temple in a private residence. At the time, Seunim Sugyeong had finished his studies under him and hoped to build a proper temple. The templeâ€™s founder and about 500 believers, a large number at the time, supported his wishes, and Seunim Sugyeong became the templeâ€™s first ğ˜«ğ˜¶ğ˜«ğ˜ª, or abbot. The temple was then rebuilt in 1987 into the current 40-pyeong (approx. 130 sqm) main hall.

In 1995, the Seogwangsa Choir was formed when Seunim Seonggeun took office as the templeâ€™s second juji. Five years later, he established the Buddhist Social Welfare Center in a 50-pyeong (approx. 150 sqm) two-story building on the east side of Doryang, creating a choir practice room as well as Gwaneumjeon, a shrine for AvalokiteÅ›vara, a tenth-level bodhisattva associated with great compassion.

Caption:
Karma Chagme Rinpoche said that although all sentient beings had, at one time or another, been his mother, as they have no memory of that relationship, they feel free either to attack him or remain strangers. We, on the other hand, know of our connection; how, then, can we not be friendly with everyone?

- Dzongsar Khyentse Rinpoche

Caption:
Het is de week van de mentale gezondheid ğŸ’š

Vrijdag 7 juni geef ik twee lessen: de eerste bij @obamsterdam Javaplein. Deze is speciaal gericht op het effect van Japanse yoga op je mentale en emotionele gezondheid. Stuur mij een mailtje of berichtje als je mee wil doen: 
info@mariskagunsing.com
Neem je eigen matje mee. 
Deelname is gratis.

De tweede les is bij @samana_yoga_center, gericht op hoe je in de komende drukte van de zomer balans blijft vinden tussen activiteit en ontspanning. 
Stuur mij een mailtje of berichtje als je mee wil doen. Matjes zijn aanwezig en deelname is op donatie basis.

Caption:
In every disappointment there is an opportunity to wake up: disappointments reveal our attachment to expectations. 

Being human requires us to look ahead and imagine the future, so expectations are not inherently bad. It is when we get attached to our expectations - when we refuse to adjust them, that we get into trouble. 

Any time you feel disappointed is a good opportunity to observe yourself. The length of time that the disappointment persists, reveals the extent to which youâ€™ve become attached to your expectations. 

Expectations - our amazing, uniquely human skill to imagine the future - should serve us, not make life harder on us. 

So whenever you find yourself to be disappointed, ask yourself what (implicit) expectations were violated. These expectations are of your own making. They only exist in your mind. 

Disappointments, in this sense, wake us up to reality. Try looking at disappointments with curiosity. Where have you accidentally gotten attached to an illusion of your own making?

__________

Caption: ì²œìˆ˜ê´€ìŒ ë¸”ë™ì•¤ê·¸ë ˆì´

ğŸ§˜ Personal Practice Retreat â€“ Days 2 & 3 re-cap

Prof Paul Gilbert, Choden and our delegates were joined by Dr William Van Gordon for Days 2 & 3 of our Personal Practice Retreat at Colwick Hall in Nottingham (UK) & Online last week.

William was a Buddhist Monk for 10 years and is now a Chartered Psychologist and Associate Professor of Contemplative Psychology at the University of Derby.

â˜¸ï¸ Delegates continued their experiential journey with a series of practices which aimed to develop understanding of ultimate bodhicitta and its two main components: awareness and emptiness. 

Following a series of morning practices and a silent mindful lunch, delegates explored the Buddhist wisdom principle of emptiness, used to address the tendency that individuals often see and interact with the world in a highly self-orientated and ego-driven manner.

Finally, Day 3 focused on Integration and explored how both biological and transcendental approaches can work together and inform our practice and teaching of compassion, including the use of mantras and visualisations to help cultivate our compassionate self and mind.

The feedback received so far has been very positive and we have really enjoyed spending the 3 days with everyone both in-person and virtually.

ğŸ™Thank you so much to everyone who joined us.

If you would like to be notified of similar events, sign up for our free newsletter via our website to join our mailing list https://i.mtr.cool/epurokaloz

Caption: Dalit Panther Foundation Day.\nThe Dalit Panthers is a social organisation that seeks to combat caste discrimination. It was led by a group of Mahar writers and poets, including Raja Dhale, Namdeo Dhasal, and J. V. Pawar in some time between the second and the third semester of 1972.It was founded as a response to the growing discontent among the Dalit youth during the 25th Independence Day celebrations. Inspired by the Black Panther movement in the United States, poet-writers J V Pawar and Namdeo Dhasal founded the Dalit Panthers, urging a boycott of the Independence Day revelry, terming it a â€˜Black Independence Dayâ€™. The movementâ€™s heyday lasted from the 1970s through the 1980s, and it was later joined by many Dalit-Buddhist activists.\n#dalitpanther #jaybhim #buddhism
Hashtags: dalitpanther, jaybhim, buddhism

Caption: In a sense everything is dreamlike and illusory, but even so, humorously you go on doing things. For example, if you are walking, without unnecessary solemnity or self-consciousness, lightheartedly walk toward the open space of truth. When you sit, be the stronghold of truth. As you eat, feed your negativities and illusions into the belly of emptiness, dissolving them into all-pervading space. And when you go to the toilet, consider all your obscurations and blockages are being cleansed and washed away. #DudjomRinpoche #LamaSuryaDas #Dzogchen #Meditation  #Mindfulness #SelfInquiry #NonDual  #Buddhism #Healing #Wellness #Yoga  #Dharma #AwakeningtheBuddhaWithin #Awareness #HowtoHeal

Caption:
The Kalachakra is a stunning visual representation of the cosmic wheel of time. In its intricate details, it conveys the the concept of how the universal cycles of the planets are one and the same with the cyclical processes of human life - breathing, sleep, birth, death...

To meditate on the Kalachakra is a deep reflection of the temporary nature of all reality. "This too, shall pass."

Caption:
The evolution of Waterloo House and its entwined connection with UK dance music. 

The Assembly Rooms, Leeds, behind the Corn Exchange, first opened in 1777, was always place of joy and community (and dancing!). In the 90s it was home to BackToBasicsâ€™ â€œRehabâ€. So-called as a 2 finger response to the media of the time referring to UK rave-goers as â€œThe chemical generationâ€. And now it continues not just as a place of love and community, but as a light in a darkening world where people can learn that thereâ€™s a different way through this life. Revealing how peace can be found no matter how difficult things get. 

1. BackToBasicsâ€™ â€œRehabâ€. 
2. The same view now! Meditation room.
3. Evening of view of the Assembly Rooms / Waterloo House as it is now @meditationinleeds 
4. Founder and CEO of BackToBasics @davebeero and Resident Teacher @gendornying @meditationinleeds 
5. Coming together. Gen Dornying and Dave Beer and 1000s of seekers at @soakevents and @fac51thehaciendaofficial amazing event in leeds in May 
6. On the stage with @wearekklass 
7. @davebeero , @rowetta and @gendornying 
8. @gendornying teaching on happiness at @meditationinleeds

Caption:
"Now until the dualistic identity mind 

melts and dissolves, 

it may seem that we are parting. 

Please be happy. 

When you understand the dualistic mind, 

there will be no separation from me. 

May my good wishes fill the sky." 

~ Yeshe Tsogyal

Source ğŸ™ Erik Jensen ğŸŒ·

That's why they say in dzogchen nothing is forbidden, but it is up to you to decide who you are as you engage in any activity. Of course other people are deceiving you. Other people are trying to hook you into being this familiar form. Because if you are you they think you are then that is confirming who they think they are...breaking free is very difficult when there are lots if people who want to keep you in the addictive, mutually confirming cycle of samsara. That is why dharma is saying if you want to practice dharma go to a place where no one know your name. Because nobody will be able to out their projections onto you...As we know attachment is very sticky and the ego is very wobbly and anxious. It wants confirmation. It wants reassurance. So you can spend alot of time in mutual grooming, in combing each other, taking the lice out, saying your lovely, you are wonderful, you are really nice and then you die. So it is not about abandoning the world or rejecting the world. It is not about renunciation it is always about the question don't blame the object, don't blame the other people. Other people are entitled to be however they are. They can be friendly or annoying of whatever they are. That's just how they are. My focus is who am I

- James Low

Caption: The rays of blessing light of the Buddha of Infinite Light touched a lotus in the Milk Ocean in the Southwest direction from Bodhgaya. That was twelve years after the Maha Parinirvana of the Buddha. As a result, Guru Rinpoche was born miraculously in that lotus. He had a â€œlotus birth" without human parents. This is why he is called Padmasambhava, the Lotus Born.Guru Padmasambhava was known in Tibet as one of the founding fathers of Tibetan Buddhism, who appeared in Tibet in 749 A.D, and spent 54 years.His love is unconditional, whether you are a good person or bad. He has boundless power to fulfill your needs, if you are mentally and karmically open.\n\n. #thangka #art #tibetan #fyp #foryou #peace #buddhism #buddha #boudha #history #handmade #painting #gold #natural #artschool #handcrafted

Caption:
Goreicha, the Tea of the Spirits at Ichibata Yakushi Temple ğŸµ

Since ancient times, tea has been considered to be a medicine to cure many diseases in Japan. Tea was introduced to Japan from China at the same time as Buddhism. Tea was said to be an elixir that could improve the drinkerâ€™s health and grant them a long life. Ichibata tea also has a long history and the name â€œIchibataâ€ comes from â€œIchi no Bataâ€ which could be translated as â€œthe first medicine gardenâ€ of the Buddha of medicine and healing, Buddha Yakushi Nyorai.

Goreicha means â€œtea of the spiritsâ€ and it is a special tea harvested in Ichibata in Izumo. Ichibataâ€™s Goreicha tea leaves are first used as an offering to Buddha Yakushi Nyorai during prayer and are shared with worshippers afterwards. If you buy a pack of tea to drink at home, it should be brewed in boiling water for 5 to 10 minutes to enjoy its full taste and aroma.

You can also taste the OchatÅ, the â€œtea of the faithâ€ when visiting the temple. OchatÅ is Goreicha when brewed in the â€œwater of the spiritsâ€. This water comes from the well located in the temple's sacred grounds and thus from the mountain where the temple is located. In the temple grounds, there is a dedicated place with a sign reading â€œãŠèŒ¶æ¹¯â€ (OchatÅ) where you can buy an original Ichibata Yakushi temple bottle (500ï¿¥/ around 3.50â‚¬) and fill it with OchatÅ. It is said that it is good for the body and the eyes, so donâ€™t hesitate to enjoy it if you come to visit the temple.

Caption:
HYBRID LECTURE AND DISCUSSION >
Dr Elizabeth Harris is President of the UK Association for Buddhist Studies and Honorary Senior Research Fellow at the University of Birmingham, having gained her doctorate in Buddhist Studies from the University of Kelaniya, Sri Lanka. A regular contributor to BBC Radio 4â€™s Thought for the Day, Elizabeth has written widely on Buddhist Studies and Buddhist-Christian issues.
When defending Buddhism against British colonialism, Anagarika Dharmapala sometimes spoke negatively about Christianity. Yet he accepted hospitality from Christians and talked with them with knowledge and respect. Dr Harris uses Dharmapalaâ€™s writings and unpublished diaries to explain what insights may be gained for today, reflecting on how interfaith relations can be both harmed and encouraged in the modern world.
The British MahaBodhi Society is delighted that the discussion on this important topic will be joined by Venerable Akurula Samitha from the Milton Keynes Vihara.

Caption:
## **æ¢é•·é½¡ (Liang ChangLing)**

Kwong Siew Association Pioneers. He is from Xinhui. A graduate of the University of Hong Kong, he once served as an inspector of schools in this country. Later, he left the educational field to enter business and was repeatedly elected as a member of the Selangor State Assembly. He served as the Cultural Director of the Malaysian Chinese Association (MCA) and as the Vice President of the MCA Selangor branch. He advocated for rural education and adult education classes. The Sultan of Selangor appointed him as a Justice of the Peace.

## Brief History

The â€œGuandi Temple,â€ also known as the [Kwong Siew Association], was established in 1888. A majestic and traditional Kwong Siew Association building was founded in Kuala Lumpur. In 1896, seven pairs of wooden columns were replaced with stone columns. In 1912, the association underwent repairs, including replacing the corridor tiles. In 1924, the back kitchen was demolished and rebuilt, adding another floor for storing equipment. Additionally, windows were added to the front corridor, and the horizontal entrance was modified. The wooden railings in the main hall were replaced with glass, and the atriums in front of the auxiliary shrines were covered with glass. Despite frequent repairs, the original design has largely remained unchanged.

Caption:
Our handcrafted Ashtamangala plate, adorned with the Eight Auspicious Symbols, is more than just a stunning wall decor piece. It embodies the essence of spiritual and material well-being rooted in Himalayan Buddhism.

The symbols include:

The Parasol: Offers protection from negative influences and symbolizes royalty.

The Pair of Golden Fish: Denotes spiritual release and fearlessness in samsara.

The Treasure Vase: Represents long life, health, wealth, and prosperity.

The White Lotus: Embodies spiritual purity and enlightenment, growing from the mud of samsara.

The Conch Shell: Signifies the spread of Dharma teachings, awakening beings from ignorance.

The Endless Knot: Represents the interconnection of all things and the cycle of rebirth.

The Victory Banner: Symbolizes the triumph of Dharma over negativity and ignorance.

The Wheel of Dharma: Guides beings towards enlightenment with the Noble Eightfold Path.

Bring home this beautiful wall decor and infuse your space with spiritual and material well-being. 
Limited stock available!

Caption:
I gave a talk the other day and opened with this story, so I thought Iâ€™d share it here.

(Itâ€™s pretty straight forward and on the nose for a Zen story, to be fair. Look up the koan â€˜Nansenâ€™s catâ€™ for one a bit more nonsensical ğŸ˜‚).

I know the word â€˜mindfulnessâ€™ is off putting for some of you. I know, ironically, what images it evokes. But really, REALLY, itâ€™s just cultivating the ability to pay attention, so that we can recognise everything for what it is, what it really is, and live from a place of clarity, instead of being bounced around by the stories we tell ourselves.

Thereâ€™s doesnâ€™t have to be anything â€˜softâ€™ or esoteric, or even necessarily â€˜spiritualâ€™ about it. Itâ€™s just having the bravery to step back into not-knowing, letting go of all of our preconceived ideas about the world, and then cultivating the attention to see whatâ€™s really here, before we get pulled into the gravity well of our own stories.

#thepathisthegoal #zen #meditation #selfinquiry #mindfulness #buddhism #mindset #mentalhealth
Hashtags: meditation, zen, mentalhealth, mindset, selfinquiry, thepathisthegoal, mindfulness, buddhism

Caption:
ğ—§ğ—›ğ—˜ ğ—œğ— ğ— ğ—¨ğ—§ğ—”ğ—•ğ—Ÿğ—˜ ğ—¥ğ—˜ğ—”ğ—Ÿğ—œğ—§ğ—¬

Ignorant beings perceive a universe with a multiplicity of objects subject to constant change. Actually, the perception of the universe is not different from the universe itself because it is this very erroneous perception which creates a universe. When ignorance is dispelled, perception changes, and what was seen as a universe of objects is now seen as an indivisible, immutable space-like reality which absolutely nothing can alter. All thinking and all sensations are nothing but space-like forms. 

Thus, we have in Advaita the following verses:

 Maka tidak akan mudah membuat karma buruk.
 
Tanya jawab 03 November 2017

Caption:
Jangan menyindir orang lain

Banyak orang yang tidak pintar, 
Sering mengucapkan kata-kata sinis untuk menyindir orang lain,
Untuk mengintimidasi orang lain, untuk merendahkan orang lain,

Untuk menonjolkan diri sendiri, *sering membongkar keburukan orang lain, membahas tentang kesalahan orang lain*, 

harus diketahui, yang seperti ini tidak hanya akan kehilangan keberuntungan, 

juga akan menghilangkan berkah diri sendiri.

Caption:
*Bolehkah sambil makan sambil melafal paritta?*

Pendengar wanita:Â Kemarin, saya tidak sengaja mendengar Master berkata bahwa boleh melafalkan paritta sambil makan. Bolehkah melafalkan paritta sambil makan?
Master menjawab:Â Orang yang bervegetarian bisa melafalkan, tetapi orang yang non-vegetarian tidak boleh. Jika mau melafalkan, hanya boleh melafal paritta pendek, tidak boleh melafalkan paritta besar. Seperti paritta Jie Jie Zhou boleh dilafalkan (oh, begitu) Jika ada nama Bodhisattva tidak boleh melafalnya (oh)

Rudraksha bracelet
.
The Rudraksha beads I have brought directly from Nepal. In Korea, they are sold as â€˜Bodhi seedsâ€™, but Rudraksha is different from Bodhi seeds. The Rudraksha from Nepal is larger and heavier than the Indian Rudraksha, so it is considered more precious.

This product is the basic 5-faced Rudraksha. It is good for overall health, well-being, and freedom. It helps lower blood pressure, calm the nerves, and bring peace and focus to the nervous system.

I will upload more detailed information about Rudraksha.

The Rudraksha is designed with Karen silver and Indian agate, which complement each other well, giving a sense of elegance and cuteness. The two ends of the bracelet are in the shape of a Vajra 

*All products are custom handmade, one and only in the world.

Master Jun Hong Lu : 

Bervegetarian adalah berkah. Orang yang bervegetarian penuh, akan terhindar dari musibah dan bencana. 

Jika anda bervegetarian sehari, Dewa Pelindung akan melindungi anda sehari.

Anda bervegetarian setiap hari, maka Dewa Pelindung akan melindungi anda setiap hari.

27 Mei 2016

Caption: Went today to this really pretty Buddhist temple called @hsilaitemple  just to see what all the hype was about and I have to say that the temple was a very relaxing and calm place to visit. I did a little prayer in front if this shrine, walked around the WHOLE temple, saw a mini museum of the history of buddhism, saw some pretty gardens located around this shrine. Before you guys do come just a heads up you NEED to dress conservatively as in nothing vulgar or anything showing your body out of respect.  #hsilaitemple #roadtrip #haciendaheights #buddhism #buddha #calmspace #sundayfunday #somethingnew #miniadventure #losangeles
Hashtags: losangeles, buddha, miniadventure, somethingnew, sundayfunday, hsilaitemple, roadtrip, buddhism, haciendaheights, calmspace
